metadata.case_name: Ladli Prasad v. Karnal Distillery Company Ltd. & Ors.

facts.text: Kishori Lal Jaiswal started distillery business as Kishori Lal Sons, factory at Kamal, Punjab.
Kishori Lal died in 1928, survived by three sons: Durga Prasad, Ladli Prasad, Shanti Prasad. Durga Prasad became karta, continued business.
Durga Prasad died in 1934, survived by sons Sajjan Lal, Madan Lal, wife Suraj Mukhi. Ladli Prasad became karta, continued business.
Joint Hindu family disrupted on November 5, 1940; business of Kishori Lal Sons conducted as partnership, each branch one-third share.
Karnal Distillery Company Ltd. incorporated March 23, 1941 under Indian Companies Act, 1913; took over business.
Final share allotment August 1, 1941: Durga Prasad branch 1005 shares, Ladli Prasad 1503, Shanti Prasad 1003.
Articles of Association: max 5 directors, min 2. First directors: Ladli Prasad, Shanti Prasad, Suraj Mukhi. Ladli Prasad Managing Director for 10 years, renewable.
Ladli Prasad remuneration: Rs.1800/month, 7.5% net profits commission, Rs.350 car allowance, new car every 3 years, Rs.30/day TA. Other directors Rs.250/month + Rs.25/meeting.
Disparity in remuneration caused quarrels.
EGM February 20, 1945: Shanti Prasad, Sajjan Lal, Madan Lal, Suraj Mukhi present; resolved to remove Ladli Prasad as MD, appoint Shanti Prasad.
Ladli Prasad refused to hand over charge. Shanti Prasad filed suit April 10, 1945 on behalf of Company for declaration and enforcement.
Ladli Prasad filed suit declaring Shanti Prasad ceased to be director.
Trial court appointed Suraj Mukhi and Madan Lal joint receivers. Ladli Prasad appealed to Lahore High Court, stay obtained.

EGM October 16, 1945 at Ladli Prasad's residence, all family present: equalized shares (1170 each, transfers effected); cancelled Feb 20 res; accepted Ladli resignation as MD, appointed permanent Director and Chairman; Madan Lal director vice Suraj Mukhi; max directors 3, quorum 3; all decisions unanimous; Shanti Prasad Manager 5 years; remuneration equal Rs.900/month + Rs.25/meeting; no extra; ratified past accounts/transactions; deleted Art 47; amended Articles.
Effect given: Shanti Prasad took charge as Manager, shares readjusted.
Board meeting March 3, 1946 (Shanti Prasad, Madan Lal present, no notice to Ladli): resolve EGM March 28 to cancel Oct 16 resolutions.

EGM March 28, 1946 (no notice Ladli Prasad): cancelled Oct 16 amendments, restored original Articles inc Art 47; removed Ladli as Director/Chairman, appointed Suraj Mukhi; Shanti MD 10 years, extra pay.
Ladli Prasad petition May 1, 1946 Lahore High Court for winding up; single judge ordered, set aside Jan 19, 1956.
Ladli Prasad suit Nov 26, 1946 Senior Sub Judge Karnal: declare March meetings illegal, Oct resolutions operative, injunction vs defendants (Company, Shanti, Suraj, Sajjan, Madan).
Defendants WS: Oct resolutions by coercion/undue influence.
Trial court (Sub Judge) May 25, 1953: no proof coercion/undue influence (no particulars, no evidence despite opportunities); March resolutions invalid (no notice, fraud); decree for plaintiff.
District Judge appeal: Oct resolutions invalid (Ladli dominated, undue advantage); March invalid but no relief as plaintiff relied on invalid res; dismissed suit.

High Court Bishan Narain J (second appeal): District findings beyond pleadings, only pleaded facts proved; Oct res valid compromise; March invalid; decree for plaintiff, proviso no affect third parties.
Division Bench Letters Patent Appeal: reversed single judge, Ladli undue influence, no injunction (inequitable conduct, deadlock); dismissed suit. Oct 18, 1957.
Certificate under Art 133(1)(a)(b); appeal to SC.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court was competent to grant certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) or (b) of the Constitution.
Whether Bishan Narain J. transgressed s.100 CPC restrictions in reversing District Judge.
Whether resolutions dated October 16, 1945 were vitiated by undue influence.
Whether resolutions dated March 3 and 28, 1946 were invalid for lack of notice and ultra vires.

petitioner_arguments.text: Defendants' plea of undue influence lacked particulars as required by O.6 R.4 CPC; no evidence led despite opportunities; burden on defendants not discharged.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: O.6 R.4 CPC; S.16 Indian Contract Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Resolutions Oct 16, 1945 result of compromise after negotiations; accounts scrutinized; acted upon by parties; no unconscionable advantage to petitioner.
March 1946 meetings without notice to petitioner, breach of Oct resolutions/Articles requiring unanimity/quorum.
Single judge correct; Division Bench erred in finding undue influence beyond pleadings.

respondent_arguments.text: Oct 16 resolutions obtained by undue influence/coercion; Ladli Prasad dominated will as elder brother/former karta, in possession of assets, used funds for litigation, helpless defendants.
Petitioner obtained unfair advantage: discharge from past liabilities without accounts scrutiny, veto power via unanimity.
No injunction: inequitable conduct, would cause deadlock requiring winding up; suggest s.155 Companies Act.
Certificate incompetent: Division Bench affirms District Judge (court immediately below); no substantial question of law.

court_reasoning.text: Certificate competent: Single Judge (appellate jurisdiction) is 'court immediately below' Division Bench under Letters Patent; appeal lies without substantial law question if valuation met.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Long practice approved; no distinction original vs appellate jurisdiction single judge.

court_reasoning.text: Second appeal admissible: undue influence finding not pure fact; based on no particulars/evidence, wrong burden; s.100 CPC grounds met.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plea lacked specifics; O.6 R.4 requires dates/items.

court_reasoning.text: No undue influence: Defendants failed to prove position to dominate (family severed, prior revolt Feb 1945) or unconscionable transaction (remuneration reduced, shares equalized, accounts scrutinized per evidence); burden not shifted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence led by defendants despite opportunities; acted upon resolutions.

court_reasoning.text: March resolutions invalid: no notice, breach unanimity/quorum; all lower courts agreed.

holdings.text: Single Judge of High Court in appellate jurisdiction is 'court immediately below' Division Bench for Art.133 certification.
Undue influence plea requires precise particulars; defendants failed to discharge burden under S.16 Contract Act.
March 3/28, 1946 resolutions invalid, not binding on petitioner.

precedents_cited.relevance: Practice of appeal from Division Bench reversing single judge original jurisdiction without substantial law question.
Single judge appellate not 'immediately below'; SC disagrees.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satgur Prasad v. Har Narain Das
precedents_cited.relevance: Undue influence finding is question of fact if fairly tried.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bharat Dharma Syndicate v. Harish Chandra
precedents_cited.relevance: Particulars essential for fraud/undue influence pleas.
Full particulars required for undue influence; no departure in evidence.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines undue influence; burden shifts only if dominance and unconscionability proved.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Second appeal grounds; particulars in pleadings for undue influence; court immediately below.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Incorporation, Articles of Association governing meetings/directors.

statutes_cited.name: Companies Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Suggested relief for rectification of register.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for SC appeal; valuation and affirmation test.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; decree of Bishan Narain J restored subject to proviso protecting third parties; declaration that Oct 16, 1945 resolutions operative, March 1946 resolutions invalid and not binding on appellant; injunction granted with undertaking not to question third party dealings.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration and permanent injunction as prayed, subject to reservations protecting third parties.

key_quotes.text: "A plea of undue influence must... be precise and all necessary particulars... must be embodied in the pleading."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes pleading requirements under O.6 R.4 CPC.

key_quotes.text: "Where it is proved that a person is in a position to dominate the will of another... and... transaction appears... unconscionable the burden... lies upon the person in a position to dominate."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains S.16(3) Contract Act presumption conditions.

key_quotes.text: "The defendants having failed to submit themselves... a strong presumption arose against the defendants."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Trial court's observation on lack of evidence.
